articles.title: APRIL IN THE YEAR 1978
articles.summary: This document outlines the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) event schedule for April and May 1978. It details various activities including public and indoor star parties, general meetings featuring guest speakers like James Ryan discussing a 1977 eclipse cruise, and board meetings. The calendar also notes activities sponsored by the AANC and an upcoming Riverside Telescope Makers Conference.

articles.title: Report of the March 3 General Meeting
articles.summary: The March 3 General Meeting included announcements of Comet Bradfield's discovery and a call for Astronomy Day volunteers, followed by a detailed talk on the Space Telescope's specifications and 1983 launch plans. A subsequent March 11 star party at Coe was marred by extreme weather, preventing observations of the new comet. The report also notes the passing of club member Tony Di Canzo.

articles.title: Astronomy Day at the Rosicrucian Planetarium
articles.summary: Astronomy Day at the Rosicrucian Planetarium was a significant success, drawing an estimated 300-400 attendees who actively engaged with nine telescopes and binoculars until late evening. The event highlighted public enthusiasm for astronomy, featuring various humorous and amazed reactions from sightseers observing the Moon and Saturn.

articles.title: TO ED SCHELL'S PLACE
articles.summary: This document provides detailed directions to Ed Schell's Place at 152 Carlton Ave. Apt. 4, Los Gatos, specifically for an "APR. 19 BOARD MEETING" scheduled for 3:00 PM. It outlines turn-by-turn instructions from San Jose, starting from Highway 17, and mentions a hand-drawn map illustrating the route. The meeting is open to everyone.

articles.title: Blurbs
articles.summary: This 'Blurbs' article compiles various club updates, including the rescheduling of the West Valley star party due to rain, an upcoming call for club elections, and an appeal for members to volunteer as reporters. It also features personal notes such as recent member birthdays, a new birth announcement, and discussions around finding a venue for the July election banquet, alongside a reminder about a regional swap meet.

articles.title: Notes from the Board Meeting at Penny Pinschmidt's house on March 10th as reported by Debbie Moore
articles.summary: This document contains notes from a board meeting covering discussions about a rescheduled star party, nominations for an amateur astronomy award, and the annual club banquet. It also includes an excerpt from an IAU Circular detailing the observation of the X-ray source 4U 0241+62, which, through combined X-ray, optical, and radio data, was identified as a distant QSO or Seyfert galaxy approximately 850 million light years away.

articles.title: EDITORAL
articles.summary: The editorial by Penny G Armstrong reports that no significant events occurred last month that warranted a detailed editorial. Essentially, there is nothing new or noteworthy to report from the past month.

articles.title: Visual Binary Stars for the Year 1980 ...conclusion
articles.summary: This concluding section of a paper on visual binary stars for 1980 provides a concise bibliography for readers interested in further studying double star orbits. The author, Gerald W. Rattley, lists 12 key astronomical sources, including books, atlases, and catalogues, utilized in his research, noting that some data was processed by his own computer program. He also references the Lick Observatory Library and other university astronomical libraries as valuable resources.

articles.title: Rattley Rattles
articles.summary: The author introduces a new monthly article series called "Rattley Rattles," which will feature "Chart Talks" detailing the best deep-sky objects for amateur observation on specific Skalnate Pleso Atlas charts, compiled from personal experience and Herschel's list. This project actively seeks club member participation for object suggestions and feedback, and will also continue a separate series on orbital diagrams of bright visual binaries. The article concludes by mentioning two external articles of interest in Science News and Scientific American.

articles.title: AD AD AD AD
articles.summary: This document contains an advertisement for a set of three Cave orthoscopia eyepieces (6mm, 12Â½mm, 25mm), similar to Meade Series 1, available for $35 or $13 each. Additionally, it includes a quote from Jim Van Nuland incorrectly stating that Mars has four satellites.

articles.title: Red Spot Predictions
articles.summary: This article provides observational guidance for locating the faint Red Spot on Jupiter, noting its position relative to a 'dent in the belt' and stressing the requirement for excellent seeing. It also includes a table of meridian transit times for a 'Great Gray Spot' and encourages observers to share their successes to help others.

articles.title: CB Channels at events
articles.summary: Jim Van Nuland proposes a standardized CB channel protocol for communication at Star parties and meetings. Channel 20 is recommended for general site monitoring, ideally by an on-site person. Channel 14 is suggested for handy-talkie use once a second person arrives, with a note to minimize its use in town due to local side-band conventions.

articles.title: Tom Bullock Quiz 1
articles.summary: The article, titled "Tom Bullock Quiz 1," presents a series of statements covering various fundamental concepts and historical aspects of astronomy. It touches upon contributions from figures like Galileo, Copernicus, Ptolemy, and Newton, as well as topics such as the solar system, galaxy, electromagnetic waves, telescopes, and common astronomical misconceptions. The content seems designed to test or review basic astronomical knowledge.

articles.title: Jeff Lo
articles.summary: Jeff Lo is actively promoting Ben Mayer's blinking program in San Jose, encouraging amateur astronomers to photograph specific sky areas and use a blink comparator to discover new celestial objects such as supernovae. He built his own blinker based on a Sky & Telescope design and invites others to participate in this rewarding program, offering a $250 reward for the first new object discovered.

articles.title: Excerpts from IAU Circulars about Comet Bradfield (1978d) out out, pasted-up copies
articles.summary: This document compiles excerpts from IAU Circulars concerning Comet Bradfield (1978d), presenting an ephemeris with its positional and brightness data for February to May 1978. It details improved orbital parameters computed by G. Marsden based on observations from February to March, along with corrections to a previously published ephemeris. The report also mentions the equipment used by Mr. Bradfield for his observations and includes record infrared observations from the O'Brien Observatory on March 27 ET.
